'Titus Flavius Hyrcanus' (, flourished second half of the 1st century & first
half of the 2nd century, born 73) was an aristocratic, wealthy Roman Jew.

Hyrcanus was born and raised in Rome. He was the youngest son born to the Roman
Jewish Historian Josephus, and from his third wife, an unnamed Alexandrian
Jewish woman. Fergus, The History of the Jewish People in the Age of Jesus
Christ (175 B.C. - A.D. 135) p.p.45-6 Hyrcanus was the only child to have
survived as his two other brothers had died. Fergus, The History of the
Jewish People in the Age of Jesus Christ (175 B.C. - A.D. 135) p.p.45-
6 Josephus, Flavius Josephus: translation and commentary p.170

His paternal uncle was Matthias, while his paternal grandparents were Matthias
and his wife, an unnamed Jewish noblewoman. His paternal grandmother was an
aristocratic woman who descended royalty and of the former ruling Hasmonean
Dynasty. Nodet, A search for the origins of Judaism: from Joshua to the
Mishnah p.250 His paternal grandfather had descended from the priestly
order of the Jehoiarib, which was the first of the twenty four-orders of Priests
in the Temple in Jerusalem Fergus, The History of the Jewish People in the
Age of Jesus Christ (175 B.C. - A.D. 135) p.p.45-6 and was a descendant of
the High Priest Jonathon. Jonathon may have been Alexander Jannaeus, the High
Priest and Hasmonean ruler who governed Judea from 103 BC-76 BC. Fergus, The
History of the Jewish People in the Age of Jesus Christ (175 B.C. - A.D. 135)
p.p.45-6

The name Hyrcanus means one from Hyrcania. Josephus, Flavius Josephus:
translation and commentary p.10 The Hyrcania Sea was the ancient Greek
name for the [[Caspian Sea]]. Hyrcanusâ name reveals his fatherâs favourite
monarch from the Hasmonean Dynasty and his lineage from the
dynasty. Josephus, Flavius Josephus: translation and commentary p.10
Perhaps his father, named him in honor of the Herodian Prince Julius Hyrcanus,
one of the sons Herod of Chalcis and Berenice. Josephus, Flavius Josephus:
translation and commentary p.10

As a young child his parents had divorced, because Josephus was displeased with
his motherâs habits. Josephus, Flavius Josephus: translation and commentary
p.170 His father married as his fourth and final wife, a distinguished
Greek Jewish noblewoman from Crete. With his fatherâs fourth wife, he had two
half-brothers: Flavius Justus and Flavius Simonides Agrippa. Fergus, The
History of the Jewish People in the Age of Jesus Christ (175 B.C. - A.D. 135)
p.p.45-6 Josephus, Flavius Josephus: translation and commentary
p.170

Hyrcanus was a contemporary of the ruling Flavian dynasty and NervaâAntonine
dynasty of the Roman Empire. He was alive when Josephus was compiling his
historical writings and when his father died about 100. Little is known on his
remaining life.
